Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Collaboration to Enhance Participation of Minority and Undergraduate Students in Nuclear Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a collaborative nuclear physics research program that will further our knowledge of nuclides with high ratios of neutrons to protons, which are interesting because they exhibit behavior not observed in stable nuclides. Experiments will be carried out at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) and be "day-one" ready for the upcoming Facility for Rare Isotope Beams when construction is complete. The experiments include: investigating heavy nuclei in excited states shortly before they fragment, exploring and characterizing particular states of beryllium nuclei, measuring separation energies of excited states of magnesium, as well as research and development of a new particle detector. Undergraduate and graduate students will collaborate with faculty at several US institutions to further this work and learn valuable highly technical skills. The projects will be evaluated through peer review and disseminated through presentations at national conferences, Ph.D. theses, and journal articles.

The PIs of this award are members of the MoNA-LISA collaboration, and the experiments they have planned will exploit the capabilities of the equipment that was developed at NSCL by the collaboration (a modular neutron array and a large area scintillation array). Neutron-rich nuclides are very short-lived and decay by prompt neutron emission, making the MoNA-LISA system the ideal tool to investigate these nuclei. Projects include analyzing data, implementing novel techniques to identify better and resolve isomeric nuclear states, measuring neutron-unbound states in neutron-rich nuclei, characterizing pre-fragmentation dynamics after relativistic beams interact with targets, as well as research and development toward a new gas electron multiplier based segmented target. Future experiments focus on higher Z nuclides that are possible with the current experimental setup. The students will learn valuable skills utilized in all facets of research including detector construction, data collection and analysis, and dissemination.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant had a number of goals: designing experiments to study neutron-unbound states, collaborate with nuclear physicists at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory to perform those experiments, and develop techniques to better design experiments both at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory and the future Facility for Rare Isotope Beams. An additional component was to and train undergraduate and graduate students for careers in STEM fields and establish a unique four-way collaboration between three undergraduate institutions and one historically black college institution.

The Intellectual Merit of the funded work included specific measurements of neutron-unbound states at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory, proposed experiments at Los Alamos National Laboratory to better characterize our neutron detectors, and analyzing data from the neutron-unbound state experiments as well as from experiments to better understand how beams produced at facilities such as the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory dynamically interact with targets. We looked in particular at the production of a large number of fluorine, sodium, and neon isotopes produced when a 32Mg beam interacted with a 9Be target.  We also contributed to the acquisition and analysis of work on 25O, 26O, 9He and 10Li, nuclei that are all of special interest to the nuclear structure physics community.

The Broader Impacts of the work involve not only increasing the US STEM workforce but also demonstrating ways for smaller academic institutions to leverage collaboration within a 'large lab' environments through the Modular Neutron Array (MoNA) Collaboration. Three undergraduate students directly supported by this award made meaningful contributions to the scope of work. Two are pursuing graduate studies in STEM fields and the third directly entered the STEM workforce upon graduation. This award funded participation in two experiments at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory and provided opportunities for undergraduate students to develop skills in data analysis, computer modeling, and detector characterization. The collaboration consists of a much larger cohort of undergraduate students, graduate students, post-docs, junior faculty, senior faculty, and research staff with a multi-year program in nuclear structure studies.
